Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Anti-fouling surface modifications for purification membranes
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will address the challenge of fouling on membranes used in biopharmaceutical processing. The successful application of this coating would enable increase in the membrane lifetime and product yield of various production streams as less of the valuable compounds remain trapped in the membrane. This can increase production capacity for life-saving medicines, reduce production costs and, in certain cases, enable continuous biopharmaceutical manufacturing. Furthermore, functionalization of membranes currently involve significant quantities of environmentally harmful solvents, which may be leachable during usage of the membrane. This issue is avoided in the current project by utilizing initiated chemical vapor deposition (iCVD) process which does not require any solvent. This coating technology can also be extended to other systems including wastewater purification, food & beverage production, industrial separations, and medical devices that rely on a similar functionalization.

The objective of Phase II will be to demonstrate a commercially viable manufacturing process to produce surface modifications within porous membranes using the iCVD process. Previous work in this subject has focused on top-coats on the top surfaces of reverse osmosis membranes, but the chemistries utilized have never before been demonstrated within interior structures of the membrane filters. During the Phase II work, the performance of the coatings will be optimized by using existing deposition equipment to tune the coating chemistry and process conditions to maximize the flux and throughput by minimizing protein fouling. The other main technical goal of the work will be to translate the current batch process into a continuous roll-to-roll process that is amenable to large-scale manufacturing. The outcome of this study will be a proven coating chemistry that is effective and durable in the membrane application, and an optimized manufacturing process capable of being implemented within current standards of membrane manufacturing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
DropWise Technologies Corp. provides advanced vapor coating technologies to address challenges related to fouling and corrosion for industrial and commercial end users. In this project, DropWise investigated commercial applications for thermally-initiated polymer vapor deposition processes, including a process called initiated chemical vapor deposition (iCVD) originally pioneered at MIT by Prof. Karen Gleason. 

The work consisted of three parts, each consisting of development of market techinncal requirements via extensive customer outreach; development of coating deposition reactors, deposition recipes, adhesion promotion techniques; and development of characterization metrics and techniques for evaluating coating prototypes, with the last part culminating in scale-up of the CVD process to support a full-scale commercial pilot.

The first part consisted of develpoment of surface functionalizations for porous purification membranes used in biopharmaceutical production, specifically anti-fouling functionalizations for virus filters. The iCVD process was used to produce prototype functionalized membranes and test permeability and throughput. Results demonstrated the exception ability to provide surface modification without any measurable decline in permeability. 

The second part consisted of development of a barrier coating for protecting reactive substrates from extreme corrosive conditions. A thermally-initiated CVD process was used to deposit barrier coatings onto reactive substrates which were then exposed to high-pressure (4,500 psi) high-temperature (200°F) brine conditions. Results showed the excpetional pinhole-free coatings applied by the CVD process were able to provide a higher degree of corrosion protection than other state-of-the-art barrier coatings. 

The final part consisted of development of an anti-scale coating for improving cleanability of process evaporators. Prototype coated evaporator tubes were produced and installed at several locations worldwide in live plants, and were tested for anti-scale efficacy and durability. Positive results of prototype testing led to a customer request for evaluting the coating on a full-size evaporator with over 2,000 tubes. Prototype production reactors were developed, along with a scaled-up cleaning & pretreatment work cell, to provide a coating throughput of 100 tubes per day. The tubes were installed and a mid-season inspection demonstrated the ability of the coating to significantly reduce the costs associated with evaporator cleaning. 


Last Modified: 12/06/2019
Modified by: Adam T Paxson

The first part consisted of develpoment of surface functionalizations for porous purification membranes used in biopharmaceutical production, specifically anti-fouling functionalizations for virus filters. The iCVD process was used to produce prototype functionalized membranes and test permeability and throughput. Results demonstrated the exception ability to provide surface modification without any measurable decline in permeability. The second part consisted of development of a barrier coating for protecting reactive substrates from extreme corrosive conditions. A thermally-initiated CVD process was used to deposit barrier coatings onto reactive substrates which were then exposed to high-pressure (4,500 psi) high-temperature (200°F) brine conditions. Results showed the excpetional pinhole-free coatings applied by the CVD process were able to provide a higher degree of corrosion protection than other state-of-the-art barrier coatings. Prototype production reactors were developed, along with a scaled-up cleaning & pretreatment work cell, to provide a coating throughput of 100 tubes per day. The tubes were installed and a mid-season inspection demonstrated the ability of the coating to significantly reduce the costs associated with evaporator cleaning.
